awd_titl_txt: Conference: Track 1: 2023 Rising BME Scholars Regional Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project is a three-day conference aimed at recruiting, retaining, and supporting underrepresented biomedical engineering (BME) PhD students through the postdoc, and into academic careers. The project is significant because there is a great need for a more diverse faculty pool in BME to continue to educate BME undergraduates, a group which becomes larger and more diverse every year. In addition, diversity of BME faculty increases diversity among research projects, improving the field of biomedical engineering with potential to identify solutions aimed at decreasing health disparities. 


The 2023 Rising Scholars in BME Regional Career Conference is a three-day conference held at the University of Minnesota – Twin Cities in partnership with ten regional academic institutions. The goals of the conference are to: (1) communicate the pathways to becoming an underrepresented faculty member (2) explore opportunities offered to a BME academic; (3) realize the impacts of being an underrepresented academic on classrooms, science, and society; (4) integrate diverse perspectives into the programming (academic, medical, governmental, and business sectors); (5) obtain tools to build a successful research program; and (6) meet mentors & future collaborators to expand personal networks. The proposed project would allow for over 25 Scholars to attend, as well as five postdoctoral researchers in BME.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
On June 21st, 2023, The University of Minnesota Department of Biomedical Engineering hosted the second annual Rising BME Scholars Regional Career Conference (RSC). The Rising Scholars Conference is part of a collaborative effort between several Midwestern institutions with the shared aim of inspiring underrepresented BME Ph.D. students to stay in academia through the post-doc and into faculty positions. The fact that underrepresented faculty in any field have great impact on increasing underrepresented students, and improving their experiences in academia, is well known. Increasing the diversity of the biomedical engineering professoriate is a needed step to increasing diversity of not only the student body, but also the field, as biomedical research takes steps to become more inclusive and work towards alleviating medical and health disparities in research and clinical settings. 

 

The 2023 Rising Scholars Conference, held at the University of Minnesota - Twin Cities campus, invited 27 Scholars and four post-docs. Of the invited 27, 25 Scholars attended the conference. The Scholars represented a diverse group, with 55% of the group being female, and 10% being non-binary; 24.1% being Black, and 13.8% being Latino. Scholars possessed a variety of underrepresented identities outside of race and gender, including LGBTQ+, first-generation student, first-generation American, and more. The Scholars also represented a wide range of institutions, with Scholars coming from coastal schools such as Stanford and U Mass Amherst, as well as strong Midwestern representation including University of Illinois - Chicago, University of Wisconsin - Madison, Washington University in St. Louis, and the University of Minnesota, as well as many others. The program focused on early to mid-level Ph.D. students, and thus, nine Scholars were going into their 2nd year, nine students were going into their third year, and six students were 4 years or above. Of those six more advanced students, one student has accepted a faculty position in Jordan.

 

The Rising Scholars Conference is a collaboration between several Midwestern institutions. In 2023, the sponsoring institutions were: University of Minnesota - Twin Cities (host), Washington University in St. Louis, University of Arkansas, University of Iowa, University of Kansas, University of Michigan, University of Illinois - Urbana Champaign, University of Illinois - Chicago, University of Texas at Austin, and the University of Wisconsin - Madison. The regionality of the conference was intentional, as a method of recruiting and retaining midwestern students to midwest universities. Evidence has shown that when provided with the resources and support, students prefer to settle down post-graduation near their homes and families. Midwestern institutions and the cities they are located in are also experiencing increasing diversity, and will require a faculty body that matches their increasingly diverse student population.

 

The 2023 RSC included five plenaries, three panels, and two workshops. All events had the general goal of inspiring students to remain in academia and to provide them with the tools and knowledge to do so. Some 2023 RSC events included: “Panel: Finding the Right Postdoc”, “Workshop: Finding/Being a Mentor”, and “Plenary: A Different Path: A Teaching-Focused Academic Career”. At the end of the conference, Scholars were given a feedback form that asked for their opinions on several different topics, including the topics or events that were of most utility or interest to them. The most favorably voted events were networking time, closely followed by the plenaries. Regarding the plenaries, one student reported that, “All the amazing talks given by speakers on topics not typically covered on other workshops, like the teaching focused position talk by Dr. Kyle and the finance workshop talk by Dr. Bowden, they were inspiring and insightful”, and another said that, “I really enjoyed the width [sic] of the plenary talks from mentorship to communication to finance management. I learned so many different things from this.”

 

Creating connections between Scholars and between Scholars and the sponsors was another one of our goals in this year’s RSC. We sought to provide students with a community of others with similar experiences, with the aim of providing a lifelong network. In addition to rating networking as one of the top most favored events/topics, 94% of respondents reported that they somewhat or strongly agreed with the statement, “I made a connection with someone outside of my institution that I will seek to maintain upon my return home.” One respondent stated, “Getting to talk with scholars, professors, and post docs in a more casual setting was invaluable to me. I made connections that I will keep throughout my graduate career and hopefully beyond.” 

 

Overall, the 2023 Rising Scholars Conference was a tremendous success, as evidenced by the overwhelmingly positive responses from Scholars. When asked, “How much, if any, has the Rising BME Scholars conference changed your interest in academic career paths?”, every respondent reported that there has been increase, ranging from “a little” (35%) to “a great deal” (5%).
